body.p: Your more then kind letter reached me, remailed at Mattoon to the above mentioned city where I am spending a few weeks at a brotheress-in-law, and attending the State Fair, of which I send you the Directory.

Your picture is very natural and lifelike, the ladies wanted to know what fine looking officer that is on the table? I tell ^them^ unfortunatley you are married, and they need not make the inquiry. Titles and honors do not change your old propensity for teasing I perceive from the mirthful tone of your letter.

"You must marry and want to marry ." The simple fact of my being a widow precludes the necesity of my denying what you have so
unjustly affirmed as well as a cruel and heedless world, but enough on this score, suffice it that if I had hold of your ear I should treat you as you would treat the French and English, that "how to repect my rights. Is your eye as penetrable that you can see through the mist of years and discern the exact extent to which a person is liable to change? and surely you must think I have changed my notions vastly since we met.

I could not return thanks sufficient for your kind and cordial invitation to spend the winter at your at your house, there being such "ample room in the Gov. Mansion", and I have taken it into concideration. Nothing would give me more pleasure, and I might possibly give up my school-teaching this winter, replenish my wardrobe and set out for the pleasures and amusements of a season in your city with this promise, that you will come out here first and then I could return with you. I am very timid these war-times, and should be affraieared on your side of the Ohio that some great Lion with Epulttes would get hold of me and send me on to Dixie
You say, come, do come -- what say you, and suppose you try it, so you can first concider the same reversed if you please. I would like to see you all and if cousin Sallie and all of them desire it, and I had some body to keep the Lions and Tigers off of me I would be more than delighted to suit you all, this coming season. I remember M P. Buster if he is the one that took me to Burkville and also cousin John Van Wincle, your present secretary of state. Will you please write again. My love to all.

As ever affectionally,
Your cousin
Villie

P.S. I infer that you were at the Inaugural hop. Take care sir, ^or^ you will in the absence of your wife and your more sober connections like myself and loose your equilibrium and find your arm reaching round some pretty womans waist, joining in the giddy mazes of the dance.
Your Inaugural has not reached me yet. When it does I will find out what the Copperhead think of it
